ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I audited the class
This is a great course!
I audited the course. I'm glad professor Ashton made me take the midterm because it forced me to study the material.

Question 1 - - I did not do any of the assigned reading and never felt like I was missing anything which makes me think it was not helpful).Question 7 - - Mark is one of the best professors/lecturers that I've had. In addition, it is very clear that he is devoted to education and students more than other faculty here at FES. He has the time, the energy, and the commitment that I would like to see more of here.Question 8 - - Great course.Question 10 - - Great field trips, and very helpful to learning and understanding the material. This was especially true for the better planned field trips (Yale Myers, Quabbin, URI).

With regard to question 5 about professor responsiveness to questions, Mark definitely answered student questions on field trips and in smaller group settings. But, during the lectures, there was very little opportunity for critical engagement and questioning. I would have appreciated it if Mark stopped regularly to solicit questions, demand questions, or ask questions of the students. I suppose that some years the class is too large to do this well, but at least this year, the class was small enough that it would have enhanced my in class experience to break up the lectures with some time dedicated to questions/discussion. Too often the lectures went along without enough time to critically engage/process the material, even though there were breaks midway through.

This is one of the best courses offered at FES. The out of class work is especially valuable and is really serves to drive home the material. Though there are a ton of field trips they are all worth it. I am a huge proponent of hands-on learning so if that's your thing then take this course.
Really enjoyed this class. There were a lot of field trips, but they were all useful. There's nothing quite like being able to observe Mark in the field :-)

The field trips that I was able to attend were great and really where a lot of the learning happens. The lectures, on the other hand, move quite slow. Mark should condense his lectures and do some of the field trips instead of Wednesday classes. Alternately, when enrolling for the class, it should indicate it meets M,W,F. Other classmates who were unable to attend the field trips due to prior commitments/other classes were at a significant disadvantage. Mark is fun and engaging, but a bit all over the place. For beginners, this is challenging. For those with some background, it is quite fun. Great beginner class for MFs, interesting for others, but not as useful.
Everyone should take this class.
Great class and introduction to silviculture.
In response to question 1. I regret not reading more of the material.

There were definitely a lot of field trips, but they were really helpful. The only thing that I struggled with was the size of the class. It is difficult on field trips to ask all of your questions and hear the professor in a large group. I didn't realize how much the field trips built on one another until the second to last field trip and our visit to Yale Myers when it all started to click.I really enjoyed the class.

The course is valuable, even to MEM'ers, because of the continuous illustration of competing values--a concept that we must all grapple with as much as possible while stakes aren't high and we're in school. This class is a continuous reminder of that.

The textbook is very helpful, much more concise and better organized than class lectures.Lots of field trips, but they are fun if a bit disorganized.Mark Ashton is a great guy, very engaged with students, enthusiastic, but it must be said that he really is a terrible lecturer. It was hard to follow along, and slides had minimal information to ground the lectures. I learned a lot more from the textbook.
Ashton's lectures!
The field trips bring the lecture material to life; time in the field is extremely valuable for overall learning
The field trips and the lectures.
Field trips, professor and TA's extensive knowledge about the subject.
Everything was great.
I took this course primarily for the field trips. It is outside my specific interests, but I knew I could learn a lot from both instructor and TAs.
The field trip. It was fun to be out in the woods with fellow foresters and with professor Ashton.
Field tripsMark's energy and lecture styleLearning some of the plant biology that I've never head beforeWriting my paper on my area of interest/research from a whole new angle.
loved being out in the field. I felt like I really learned something about my environment here in CT. the term paper was also a really great learning experience.
Field trips and Mark's sense of humor.
The practical application of knowledge in the field
Mark Ashton is a brilliant teacher, and cares so much about his students, he is the single best thing
Professor Ashton and the TAs were very knowledgeable and always accessible.
Mark is a great lecturer and you learn a lot from the lectures alone. The field trips are very well organized and you get a lot out of them too.
The field trips. I learned so much from them and really enjoyed them.
Mark, the field trips, the paper, the overnight to Yale Myers and learning about silviculture....
Professor very enthusiastic about topic.

Mark Ashton is the best professor that I have had at FES by far. He cares about the material he teaches and about the students and his efforts in preparing for the class and presenting for the material really pay off. Other professors should be held to the same standard Mark sets forth. He is someone who is truly dedicated to the students and to people learning the material.I also really like the field trips
mark ashton's creativity and care for the material.
The field trips, although they should not all have been on Fridays.
Ashton is the most dedicated Professor at FES. His lectures are clear, exams are clever, and comments are very helpful.The TAs and field trips were wonderful.
The Yale-Meyers overnight trip was the most useful and was also a lot of fun. I enjoyed the field trips that I could make it to.
Mark Ashton, the contents, and the jokes

1.) This class would not be the same without Professor Ashton. His enthusiasm for the course and care of his students really shows. He communicates the material in a way that is engaging and accessible to practitioners in a broad range of disciplines.2.) Field trips and field experience are integral to an holistic understanding of silviculture. Professor Ashton provided us with numerous valuable opportunities to engage in practical (introductory) applications of silviculture.
the field trips - absolutely
Mark Ashton
The field trips. I just wish we had a smaller group.
Excellent lectures. Well thought out.

Mark's enthusiasm for teaching, his mastery of the material, the variety in different learning settings (classroom, field, Yale-Myers, Marsh, field trips), and the emphasis on and encouragement that everyone takes something unique away from the class--it all depends on where each individual is coming from. That is palpable in this class and students are more enthused because of it.
The field trips
Mark's passion for the subject matter and commitment to the students.
Field trips, especially to Yale-Myers.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: nothing
Very time intensive. Could probably teach the same amount of material in slightly less class time.
I would encourage students to read more.
Assigned readings - many books, hard to follow what to read when.
Not be so early in the morning.
Field trip timing and organization
see question 11
Strawberry teabags.
more explanation of basics. what type of product are we managing for in field exercises? what does basal area mean again?
Not running on environmental time or more so accommodating people that run on environmental time!
Professor Ashton could benefit from pausing to take questions during his lectures, so as to keep the energy level higher during class time.

I think not every field trip needs an opening lecture and to take from 7 am till 6 pm. Some things could be abbreviated without loss of learning. I'd rather stay longer at Yale Myers to do wildlife and only go to the Quabbin the following week.
It can be a bit tough paying attention in class. I suggest not bringing a laptop and sitting in the front.
The pace, Prof. Ashton can get a little off course in lectures.
Not too much. I would eliminate the Friday lectures scheduled at the beginning of the semester as I think all of the material could be fit into the normal class hours.
mark's lectures are a bit like long lists of concepts. he's a great person, has great energy and knowledge, and he is a fantastically generous person. but the lectures were really not that helpful.
The work - maybe have 2 quizzes instead of a midterm. Space out assessments, so there are more opportunities to apply what has been learned.
The course is taught to be accessable to people with no background in science or ecology; it might be better to assume more knowledge since FES admissions generally requires some science.

Sometimes when my group got a wrong answer on a field trip exercise, or just didn't understand how to calculate something correctly, we never really went over how to do it the right way. I wish we had gone over the exercises together after doing them in groups to solidify how it's supposed to be done, because there were definitely times when my group was way off and we weren't sure why.
Homework
n/a
Prof Ashton should recommend fewer, more focused readings - samples, not entire texts - this will increase the odds that students will actually read them
more information needed on the slides.

I don't think that we (the students) as a group used the TA sessions wisely. It seemed like no one really prepared for them and so they ended up not being that helpful. I am not sure how to fix it though.
The lectures were poorly timed, some topics went over the time at the expense of the next topic or concept.
Nothing really. As long as the class is updated to reflect on silvicultural history while advancing it at the same time, this course is a great vehicle for that.
The study session lead by the TA's
Better structure! It was so hard to learn from the lectures. I wish there was more information in the slides.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both super responsive
all were excellent
Great
Great.
Very good.
TAs were available, responsive, and helpful/
The TAs and Mark were super responsive.
Excellent......... they were both brilliant.
Both Tom and Marlyse were very helpful as TAs, leading informative review sessions.

The TA's were great. They ran review sessions before the midterm and final as well as tutorials throughout the course of the semester and always made themselves available. Mark is very busy but he always makes time to see students outside of class.
Excellent and available. Really great all around.
very helpful. prompt responses to email.
The TAs were a bit apathetic but always made themselves available. Mark was always available and very helpful.
TAs were frequently available and helpful even beyond the scope of the class.
Excellent. They were very accessible and willing to help.
n/a
very helpful
Mark was excellent. TA sessions were not particularly helpful.

Professor Ashton is really wonderful at making time for students. He was always available to answer questions and provide advice. Marlyse and Tom were great. They were also very available outside of class to give advice in the paper or explain concepts from the field trips and class.
Good guidance on my paper. Availability whenever needed. Couldn't ask for a lot more.
Instructor and TA responded to all my doubts
They were always very available
Very willing to help, both instructor and TA.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: You would think it doesn't because I'm a policy person, but it actually totally does - it's something one should understand if they expect to go into any sort of conservation policy, campaigning, etc.
It indirectly fits into my academic interests. Overall, I just wanted to learn about forestry while at a forestry school.
It does not actually. Stands out on its own.
i don't plan on being a forester but the information presented to understand decision making in management plans and protected areas and harvest
Its a requirement for the MF degree.
I am an MF, it is crucial to my overall program.
required for the degree, also lots of useful background for future courseworkl

It doesn't fit into my program in a traditional way but after my first semester at FES I decided to take courses based on the quality of teaching of the professor and that were recommended to me by fellow students, rather than taking courses that align perfectly with my research interests. I couldn't be more happy with my decision and I will continue to pick classes based on these criteria again. I would recommend this course without reservation to anyone no matter their interests.
I study political science and law, but came to FES partially to get a better grounding in ecology and forestry as a substantive area of policy and practice. The courese was a great foundation.

It gives me an overall view on how to approach silviculture technics for restoration and conservation technics for tropical ecosystems, and the importance of getting local people involved in this kind of projects.

Though I am not an MF, the practice of silviculture employs concepts that are valuable to my course of study and to a variety of fields. The course provides an integrative perspective for land management at a variety of spatial and temporal scales and seems to bridge a lot of the more conceptual material that many other courses touch upon. I don't think that I could go through FES without taking this course.
I'm an MEM with some limited field experience in forestry. Forestry is not a focus of mine at FES.
Very useful introduction to silviculture
I am not sure. I am more on the business side of things. We will see how this all fits in!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Technical complement to policy work

I took this course to get a working knowledge in how to actively manage forest landscapes. My interests are in landscape scale land conservation, and working landscapes are a critical component of this. This course offered me the perspective of folks engaged in active forestry management, the common language and understandingto speak with them, and the knowledge of how to include these interests within the biophysical constraints of the land.
Wanted to learn basic forestry skills, both inside and outside the classroom.
I heard it was a seminal course to take at FES even though my interests are not in silviculture and forestry.
I just wanted to learn something about forestry.
It was recommended.
Important to have a foundation in silviculture as a student at FES!
Required for the MF degree.
I am an MF.
required. also an FES classic.
Because of Mark Ashton
it is a core class of this department and ashton is a legend.
For fun.
To get a foundation in forest ecology and forestry in order to be more conversant with practitioners and understand principles of managment at which to aim policy.

Because I wanted to have a background on how forests are managed and what are the different technics used. One of the main reasons for coming to F&ES was the opportunity of taking class with Mark Ashton.
It's not a requirement for me, but I would be remiss if I did not take silviculture and/or if I missed an opportunity to take a course with Professor Ashton.
general interest, potential application to research topics, heard [correctly]that it was 'not to be missed'
It is part of the MF tract
Because I knew it would be really interesting. And I wanted to take one of Mark's classes.
Interested in knowing the fuction of trees in the broader landscape management
So much good hype among students. Seems seminal to the FES education.
I took this for general knowledge of silviculture as part of natural resource management. I also took it for the experience of field trips with my classmates.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes and more!
Yes, the class was excellent and I came away having learned a lot
yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
Yes! I had heard great things about it, and I will highly recommend it to everyone I can.
Yes. FES needs about 50 Mark Ashtons. The best professor I've had here. Helpful, caring, inspiring. Cares a great deal about TEACHING and getting his students to LEARN...which is why we're here.
Totally. There is a demographic divide though - mostly first years.
It lived up to my expectations
Yes -- a great class!
Yes, one of the best classes at FES - hands down.
Exceeded expectations.
Yes.
Yes
Yes. I learned so much and enjoyed the class thoroughly.
yes, but that's not saying much.
Yes.
Exeeded by far-best class at FES.
It lived well over my expectations.
yes.
yes - and the field trips were well beyond expectations
Yes. Great class.
Yes, definitely. It has been my favorite course at FES so far.
This course was everything I thought it would be.

Yes. I learned a lot and was challenged, but not in an intimidating way. Mark was a wonderful teacher. The lectures can be a bit wayward, but it's understandable for 8:30. No one wants to be talking at that time.
Yes, it covers a good amount of material, you realize there is just so much to learn in this topic
Yes and no. Field trips were great but everything was much more scattered and difficult than expected (or necessary).

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: see above
Yes
yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes. I wish I had put more time into it.
More, actually,I hadn't expected Mark to be so good at linking social science and science together, but he really did in a very accessible, understandable, interesting way.
Yes, and much more.
Yes!
Yes.

It took until right up until the exam for me to understand everything and get a clear picture which was initially frustrating as I struggled through the midterm and skimmed over fieldwork but I got a lot out of the class.
Yes
Yes -- a strong foundation in the principals of silviculture.
Yes
Yes.
Yes

Yes and more. I leaned about forest ecology and management but it was also a wonderful opportunity to bond with many students through field trips and studying for the exams. It was also wonderful to spend time learning in the field.
yes.
Yes, and more, mark is fantastic and extreamly knowledgable
I learned a lot
Yes, however I would like to keep on taking similar classes to keep on developing the paper and projects I have in mind after taking this class.
More than. Also, I thoroughly enjoyed taking the silviculture mid-term and final.
more than expected
Yes, definitely
Yes, I did. I had to miss a few of the field trips, but was otherwise really pleased with the opprtunities in and out of class.
Yes,
An overview of silviculture; a goodtextbook resource; time spent with an enthusiastic professor and classmates.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Learning from peers on field trips was great.
MF study sessions really help - also working with the folks who took stand dynamics.
We were able to pool knowledge to better balance multiple (hypothetical) management objectives.
it wasn't frequent or comprehensive enough to be of much value.
Group work in the field was a good way to get people talking.
I liked learning from people with more forestry experience during the group work on field trips. It was a good opportunity to exchangeknowledge among students.
studying/reviewing for exams as a group was helpful

I think it's really great in field settings, like the gw at Yale-Myers. That trip begs for groupwork and people aren't quite as apprehensive about it as they might have been at MODs.Disadvantages are that people might be group worked out and are looking for trips as a time to slack off. Lame.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Even if you don't think it's useful or relevant for you, TAKE IT ANYWAY! You will find that it will be.
I will highly encourage students to take this course.
Start your silviculture paper when Mark tell you to.
Attend all field trips. Take good notes because most of the slides are pictures/tables/graphics and it will be difficult to remember their relevance later.
If you choose to audit, it is worth showing up to class and studying hard for the midterm.
Take notes on the field trips!
Take it in first year!
Read the textbooks! They are super helpful! Wear sunscreen! Check for ticks!
Go on all the field trips

Don't be intimidated by the 4 credits or the course load. There are a lot of field trips but they are very well worth it and its in the field where you really learn the material. It can be tough to stay on top of the readings but some are more important than others. No one ever does, but start your term paper early - it will make your last week of the semester that less stressful!
Do all readings that the professor gives, and try to apply all knowledge to the real life. Make hypothetical examples and think how you will manage those cases. It is all about it.
Go on the field trips and start your paper early.
Go on the field trips! (and go to class, even though it's early). Take notes on the powerpoint printout provided so you're not trying to figure out what on earth a picture was meant to tell you.

The reading is not necessary but helpful if there is a concept that you do not understand. Study hard for the tests and it will pay off. Take advantage of getting to know Mark and go on as many field trips as you can.
take it easy. let yourself soak it in.
Give mark a good draft of your paper because he gives great comments.Go on all the field trips.This course should be mandatory for all FESers (even those of us studying law and policy)

Read the textbook, because there are some concepts that the book diagrams very nicely that I didn't understand from class. I would have understood shelterwoods much earlier in the course had I kept up with the reading.
Read the weekly readings, start studying at least one week in advance for the test, and do not hesitate to ask any questions to the professor or the TAs
Go to class. Attend the field trips. Ask questions. Open your mind a little to the broad concepts, seek to understand how systems interact, and don't get bogged down in the minutia of dendrology...

make an effort to go on ALL the trips - plan to take the course your first year spring when you can follow through on this commitmentdo your best to simultaneously seek out other student groups that focus on similar topics (like SAF etc) applied experiences with these courses will help also
Take this course. It's a must.
Ask lots of questions on field trips. Talk to the TAs for clarification of class material. They often have a different perspective that is really helpful.
Start early on your paper! Turn as much in as possible during Spring Break. Otherwise, enjoy....
If you want to get a sense of silviculture take the class. The field trips are interesting and fun!
Read the textbook, and study in a group to make covering all the confusing lectures less arduous/more possible.
